bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Sarah and husband Frank Lovell were Trotskyist activists who played a significant role in the Detroit labor and socialist movements of the 1950s and 1960s. In the late 1960s, Frank and Sarah were involved in the Socialist Workers Party's trade union activity in New York City until Lovell and Sarah were expelled from the SWP in 1981.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains the personal papers of Sarah Lovell, a Trotskyist activist. Includes materials related to her involvement as a member of the International Typographical Union (ITU) Local 6 and the Coaliton of Labor Union Women (CLUW) in New York in the 1970s, including correspondence, monthly bulletins of the Local 6, records concerning the 1980 ITU Convention, and efforts by CLUW to move the convention to from Missouri to an Equal Rights Amendment ratified state. Also includes , a collection of articles compiled by the Solidarity labor commission; materials relating to the Detroit Newspaper Strike of 1968; an original copy of by Art Preis, published by the Socialist Workers Party.
